title: This $150 bourbon is made with the same water that goes into New York bagels
text:
The bottle: Widow Jane: The Vaults, $150

The back story: When we think of bourbon, we think of Kentucky, the state most associated with the classic American whiskey.

But Widow Jane, a seven-year-old company, aims to make the case that bourbon and Brooklyn go hand in hand.

That’s right: This is whiskey with a New York City pedigree. And the brand, which is indeed based in the city’s Brooklyn borough, has now released a limited-edition bourbon, aptly called The Vaults.

To be clear, Widow Jane sources the whiskey used in The Vaults, aged for at least 14 years, from out-of-state — specifically, Tennessee and Indiana (bourbon can indeed be made anywhere in the U.S.). But it adds water from an upstate New York source — specifically, Rosendale, N.Y. — to the mix.

Don’t miss: Going beyond bourbon: You can now buy ‘mixing water’ from Kentucky

“This is the New York fingerprint,” says Lisa Wicker, Widow Jane president and head distiller. She notes that the water is rich in limestone, which is a hallmark of bourbon from Kentucky, so why not see how the New York version compares?

“We thought, ‘We have that water in New York and we all know New York water makes great bagels and pizza,’” she adds.

On top of that, Widow Jane finishes aging the whiskey in Brooklyn — in the case of The Vaults, using American oak casks that have been air-seasoned for eight years. The long period of seasoning adds a “distinguished” quality to the whiskey, Wicker says.

Widow Jane, which also offers some lower-priced bourbons and ryes, must be doing something right. The company says its sales increased by 42% in 2018.

What we think about it: This is indeed a rich, heavy bourbon, something that all but demands to be sipped with consideration. The brand says you should pick up notes of tobacco and brown sugar, among other flavors. But we also detect a buttery quality. In the end, we can’t really say if the water is what’s adding to the whiskey’s sumptuous quality. But we do like a good New York bagel, so who knows?

How to enjoy it: This is too fancy a bourbon to mix in a cocktail. The brand suggests simply enjoying it neat.
description: The Widow Jane brand gives whiskey a Brooklyn pedigree.
